H0.text: Oil is the renewable energy source used to make electricity that is thought to be always available.

H1.text: Coal is the renewable energy source used to make electricity that is thought to be always available.

H2.text: Wind is the renewable energy source used to make electricity that is thought to be always available.

H3.text: Nuclear is the renewable energy source used to make electricity that is thought to be always available.

A4.text: The two most important forms of renewable energy, solar and wind, are intermittent energy sources: they are not available constantly, resulting in lower capacity factors.

A5.text: Some also consider nuclear power a renewable power source, although this is controversial, as nuclear energy requires mining uranium, a nonrenewable resource.

A6.text: Wind power is variable, so it needs energy storage or other dispatchable generation energy sources to attain a reliable supply of electricity.

A7.text: The seasonal industry might then take advantage of high wind and low usage times such as at night when wind output can exceed normal demand.

A8.text: Nuclear thus remains the dispatchable low-carbon technology with the lowest expected costs in 2025.

A9.text: Nuclear power plants, though capable of some grid-load following, are typically run as much as possible to keep the cost of the generated electrical energy as low as possible, supplying mostly base-load electricity.
